content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards under Section 32902 of title 49, United States Code, now require non-passenger automobiles to meet a minimum fuel economy standard of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. The Secretary must ensure that non-passenger automobiles manufactured for model year 2022 and beyond have a minimum fuel economy standard of 27.5 miles per gallon. Standards for passenger automobiles must be set at least 18 months before each model year, with separate standards possible for different classes based on fuel economy-related attributes. The Secretary sets maximum feasible average fuel economy levels for passenger automobiles by model year, with separate standards for different classes based on vehicle attributes. For model year 2022 and beyond, the average fuel economy standard must be at least 35 miles per gallon. The Secretary sets maximum feasible average fuel economy levels for passenger automobiles by model year, with separate standards for different classes based on vehicle attributes. For model year 2022 and beyond, the average fuel economy standard must be at least 35 miles per gallon. Additionally, an alternative minimum standard is set for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles, which is the greater of 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers. The alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles is set at the greater of 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in the model year. The alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles is determined based on the average fuel economy standard established for passenger automobiles. The Secretary must provide a transition period for the first 3 model years for manufacturers to choose between complying with attribute-based standards or a single corporate average fuel economy level. The transition period for manufacturers to choose between complying with attribute-based standards or a single corporate average fuel economy level will last for the first 3 model years. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, with existing standards remaining in effect until a new standard is prescribed. The existing standards for passenger automobiles will remain in effect until a new standard is prescribed. Manufacturers can transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to non-compliant categories, with restrictions on the transfer of credits earned after model year 2010. The term 'fleet' refers to all automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer in a specific model year, while the term 'compliance category of automobiles' includes passenger automobiles manufactured domestically and those not manufactured domestically. The term 'compliance category of automobiles' refers to 3 categories: passenger automobiles manufactured domestically, passenger automobiles not manufactured domestically, and non-passenger automobiles. The Fuel Conservation Education Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to create a public education campaign on fuel conservation for drivers. The campaign will be accessible through various media channels and the Secretary will cover up to 50% of the costs, with the option to accept private funds. The Secretary of Transportation will provide up to 50% cost sharing for a campaign to promote fuel savings to drivers. Private funds can also be accepted to supplement the funding.
